title: Hyperbolic absolute risk aversion
text:
In <a href="finance">finance</a>, <a href="economics">economics</a>, and <a href="decision%20theory">decision theory</a>, hyperbolic absolute risk aversion (HARA) refers to a type of <a href="risk%20aversion">risk aversion</a> that is particularly convenient to model mathematically and to obtain empirical predictions from. It refers specifically to a property of <a href="von%20Neumann%E2%80%93Morgenstern%20utility%20function">von Neumann–Morgenstern utility function</a>s, which are typically functions of final wealth (or some related variable), and which describe a decision-maker's degree of satisfaction with the outcome for wealth. The final outcome for wealth is affected both by <a href="random%20variable">random variable</a>s and by decisions. Decision-makers are assumed to make their decisions (such as, for example, <a href="Modern%20portfolio%20theory">portfolio allocations</a>) so as to maximize the <a href="expected%20value">expected value</a> of the utility function.
Notable special cases of HARA utility functions include the <a href="Risk%20aversion%23Absolute%20risk%20aversion">quadratic utility function</a>, the <a href="Exponential%20utility">exponential utility function</a>, and the <a href="Isoelastic%20utility">isoelastic utility function</a>.

Decreasing, constant, and increasing absolute risk aversion.
<a href="Absolute%20risk%20aversion">Absolute risk aversion</a> is decreasing if formula_12 (equivalently "T" '("W") > 0), which occurs if and only if formula_9 is finite and less than 1; this is considered the empirically plausible case, since it implies that an investor will put more funds into risky assets the more funds are available to invest. Constant absolute risk aversion occurs as formula_9 goes to positive or negative infinity, and the particularly implausible case of increasing absolute risk aversion occurs if formula_9 is greater than one and finite.

Behavioral predictions resulting from HARA utility.
Static portfolios.
If all investors have HARA utility functions with the same exponent, then in the presence of a <a href="Risk-free%20interest%20rate">risk-free asset</a> a <a href="mutual%20fund%20separation%20theorem">two-fund monetary separation theorem</a> results: every investor holds the available risky assets in the same proportions as do all other investors, and investors differ from each other in their portfolio behavior only with regard to the fraction of their portfolios held in the risk-free asset rather than in the collection of risky assets.
Moreover, if an investor has a HARA utility function and a risk-free asset is available, then the investor's demands for the risk-free asset and all risky assets are linear in initial wealth.
In the <a href="capital%20asset%20pricing%20model">capital asset pricing model</a>, there exists a representative investor utility function depending on the individual investors' utility functions and wealth levels, independent of the assets available, if and only if all investors have HARA utility functions with the same exponent. The representative utility function depends on the distribution of wealth, and one can describe market behavior as if there were a single investor with the representative utility function.
With a complete set of <a href="state%20prices">state-contingent securities</a>, a sufficient condition for security prices in <a href="Economic%20equilibrium">equilibrium</a> to be independent of the distribution of initial wealth holdings is that all investors have HARA utility functions with identical exponent and identical rate of time preference between beginning-of-period and end-of-period consumption.
Dynamic portfolios in discrete time.
In a discrete time dynamic portfolio optimization context, under HARA utility optimal portfolio choice involves partial myopia if there is a risk-free asset and there is <a href="Autocorrelation">serial independence</a> of asset returns: to find the optimal current-period portfolio, one needs to know no future distributional information about the asset returns except the future risk-free returns.
With asset returns that are <a href="Independent%20and%20identically%20distributed%20random%20variables">independently and identically distributed</a> through time and with a risk-free asset, risky asset proportions are independent of the investor's remaining lifetime.
Dynamic portfolios in continuous time.
With asset returns whose evolution is described by <a href="Wiener%20process">Brownian motion</a> and which are independently and identically distributed through time, and with a risk-free asset, one can obtain an explicit solution for the demand for the unique optimal mutual fund, and that demand is linear in initial wealth.
